ÅšÄriputra!

At that time, the Venerable SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:

The Buddha told SubhÅ«ti:

These three names are neither produced nor extinguished, only provisionally established, not within, not without, and not in between, because they cannot be apprehended.
SubhÅ«ti should know!
In the world, the self only has a provisional name. Such a nominally imputed self is neither produced nor extinguished, only provisionally established and called a self.

In the same way, sentient beings, living beings, born beings, nourished beings, persons, pudgalas, mind-born beings, young beings, agents, experiencers, knowers, and seers are also only provisional names. Such nominal designations do not arise or cease, and are only provisionally established as sentient beings up to seers.
In this way, all are only provisional names. These provisional names are neither internal, nor external, nor in between, because they cannot be apprehended.
Thus, SubhÅ«ti!

If the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, the perfection of wisdom, and these two names are all provisional dharmas, such provisional dharmas do not arise or cease, and are only provisionally established, neither internal, nor external, nor in between, because they cannot be apprehended.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
Just as internal forms are only provisional dharmas, such dharma-provisions do not arise or cease, and are only provisionally established as forms;

In the same way, feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness are also only nominally existent phenomena. Such nominally existent phenomena are neither produced nor extinguished, and are only provisionally designated as feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness.
In this way, all are only nominally existent, and these nominal designations are neither internal, nor external, nor somewhere in between, because they cannot be apprehended.
Thus, SubhÅ«ti!

Whether it is a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, or prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, or these two names, they are all nominally existent phenomena. Such nominally existent phenomena are neither produced nor extinguished, and are only provisionally designated, because they are neither internal, nor external, nor somewhere in between, and cannot be apprehended.

For example, the eye sense base is only nominally existent, and such nominal existence is neither produced nor extinguished, and is only provisionally designated as the eye sense base;

The ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind bases are also only nominally existent dharmas. Such dharmas, which are nominally existent, are neither produced nor extinguished. They are only provisionally established as the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind bases.
Thus, all of these are only nominally existent. These nominal existences are neither internal, nor external, nor somewhere in between. Because they cannot be apprehended.

Whether it is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, or prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, or these two names, they are all nominally existent dharmas. Such nominally existent dharmas are neither produced nor extinguished. They are only provisionally established, neither internal, nor external, nor somewhere in between, because they cannot be apprehended.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
For example, the form base is only nominally existent. Such nominally existent dharmas are neither produced nor extinguished. They are only provisionally established as the form base;

The same applies to the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind realms. These are also only nominally existent phenomena. Such nominally existent phenomena are neither born nor extinguished. They are only provisionally designated as the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind realms.
In this way, all of them are only nominally existent. These nominally existent phenomena are neither internal, nor external, nor somewhere in between. Because they cannot be apprehended.

Whether it is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, or prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, or these two names, they are all nominally existent phenomena. Such nominally existent phenomena are neither born nor extinguished. They are only provisionally designated. They are neither internal, nor external, nor somewhere in between. Because they cannot be apprehended.

For example, the eye realm, form realm, and eye consciousness realm are only nominally existent phenomena. Such nominally existent phenomena are neither born nor extinguished. They are only provisionally designated as the eye realm, form realm, and eye consciousness realm;

It is like the head, neck, shoulders, arms, hands, abdomen, back, chest, sides, waist, spine, thighs, knees, calves, legs, feet, and so forth of the inner body, as well as the skin, flesh, bones, and marrow, which are only provisional names. Such provisional names are neither born nor extinguished. They are only provisionally established as the head, neck, and other parts of the inner body.
In this way, all of them are only provisional names. These provisional names are neither within, nor without, nor in between the two, because they cannot be apprehended.

If the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, the perfection of wisdom, and these two names are all provisional dharmas, such provisional dharmas are neither born nor extinguished. They are only provisionally established, neither within, nor without, nor in between the two, because they cannot be apprehended.

It is like external things, such as grass, trees, roots, stems, branches, leaves, flowers, and fruits, which only have provisional names. Such nominal designations are neither born nor extinguished. They are only provisionally established as external things, grass, trees, roots, and so forth.

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, when practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, is able to cultivate the perfection of giving, is also able to cultivate the perfection of morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom;

they are able to abide in inner emptiness, and also able to abide in outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of dispersion, emptiness of inherent nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of non-existence;

they are able to abide in suchness, and also able to abide in the dharma realm, dharma nature, non-false nature, unchanging nature, equality nature, nature of detachment from birth, dharma determination, dharma abiding, reality limit, space realm, and inconceivable realm;

they are able to cultivate the four establishments of mindfulness, and also able to cultivate the four right efforts, four bases of supernatural powers, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of enlightenment, and eightfold noble path;
they are able to abide in the noble truth of suffering, and also able to abide in the noble truths of the origin of suffering, cessation of suffering, and the path to the cessation of suffering;
they are able to cultivate the four formless concentrations;
they are able to cultivate the eight liberations, also able to cultivate the eight superior realms, the nine successive concentrations, and the ten universal bases;
they are able to cultivate the emptiness liberation gate, also able to cultivate the signless and wishless liberation gates;
they are able to cultivate all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways, also able to cultivate all samÄdhi gateways;
they are able to cultivate the five eyes, also able to cultivate the six supernormal knowledges;

they are able to cultivate the ten powers of the Buddha, also able to cultivate the four fearlessnesses, the four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, and the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha.

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva at this time does not see the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, does not see the name of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, does not see prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, does not see the name of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

SubhÅ«ti!

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and well understands the true characteristics of all dharmas, because he well understands that within them there are no defiled dharmas or pure dharmas.
Thus, SubhÅ«ti!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ and awaken to the fact that the names of all dharmas and the dharmas themselves are merely nominally established.
SubhÅ«ti!

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, having truly awakened to the fact that names and dharmas are nominally established, does not grasp at form, does not grasp at feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness;
does not grasp at the eye faculty, does not grasp at the ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind faculties;
does not grasp at the form faculty, does not grasp at the sound, smell, taste, touch, or dharmas faculties;

They do not grasp at the eye-element, form-element, eye-consciousness-element, and eye-contact, up to they do not grasp at the mind-element, dharma-element, mind-consciousness-element, and mind-contact, and the various feelings that arise from mind-contact as a condition;
They do not grasp at the conditioned element, nor do they grasp at the unconditioned element;
They do not grasp at the perfection of giving, nor do they grasp at morality, patience, vigor, meditation, or wisdom;

They do not grasp at the various marks, nor do they grasp at the body of a bodhisattva, nor do they grasp at the fleshly eye up to the Buddha eye, nor do they grasp at the perfection of cognition and the perfection of spiritual powers, nor do they grasp at inner emptiness up to the emptiness of the essential nature of non-existence, nor do they grasp at bringing sentient beings to maturity, nor do they grasp at purifying a buddha-land, nor do they grasp at skillful means.
Why is it so?
SubhÅ«ti!
Because all dharmas are non-existent, the one who becomes attached, the object of attachment, the place of attachment, and the time of attachment cannot be apprehended.
Thus, SubhÅ«ti!

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, without grasping at any dharmas, when practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, increase the perfection of giving, increase the perfection of morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom, enter the bodhisattvas' correct detachment from birth, enter the bodhisattvas' irreversible ground, and perfect the bodhisattvas' sublime spiritual powers.

When the bodhisattvas' sublime spiritual powers are perfected in this way, they proceed from one buddha land to another buddha land, in order to mature all sentient beings, in order to purify their own buddha land, in order to see the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, and after seeing him, to make offerings, revere, honor, and praise him, causing all wholesome roots to grow and increase.
Having thus given rise to and increased these wholesome roots, they will be able to listen to and receive the true Dharma of the buddhas as they wish.

Having listened to and received it, they will be able to retain it without forgetting it up to unsurpassed perfect supreme enlightenment, and will attain mastery over all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways and samÄdhi gateways.
Thus, SubhÅ«ti!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ truly realize that names and dharmas are provisional, and are free from attachment.
